questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you are not confident that your vehicle will have enough room to safely pass under an overhead object, you should slow down and seek another route, if possible.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, switch gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the crossing.

questions.question: A burning tire should be:
questions.explanation: A burning tire should be cooled with water. A driver may need to use large quantities of water to properly cool the tire.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: When preparing to drive in the winter, be sure to check:
questions.explanation: Before driving during the winter, make sure to check your defrosting and heating equipment, coolant and antifreeze levels, wipers and washers, tire tread, tire chains, lights, reflectors, and exhaust system. Clear ice and snow from all windows, mirrors, hand holds, steps, deck plates, and radiator shutters. Make sure the winterfront is not closed too tightly.

questions.question: It is illegal to operate a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of:
questions.explanation: Operating a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.04 percent is illegal and will result in loss of license for at least one year for a first offense. If you operate a CMV with any detectable amount of alcohol in your system while remaining below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be put out-of-service for at least 24 hours.

questions.question: When inspecting the exhaust system, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system, be alert to a number of potential problems, including loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Federal and state laws require:
questions.answerA: Drivers to regularly inspect their vehicles.
questions.answerB: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they believe there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Drivers to inspect their vehicles if planning to travel out-of-state.
questions.answerD: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they will be transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Commercial drivers are required by federal and state laws to inspect their vehicles before every trip. Regular inspections can help drivers identify issues before they become dangerous and costly.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: If driving a vehicle with a manual transmission, you can prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when starting from a stop by:
questions.answerA: Partly engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Placing the vehicle in reverse before moving forward.
questions.answerC: Fully engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Placing the vehicle in neutral before moving forward.
questions.explanation: To prevent rolling backward when starting from a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake. Apply the parking brake whenever necessary to prevent your vehicle from rolling back.

questions.question: A driver can have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses, one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerC: A license for each state in which they plan to drive.
questions.answerD: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one license. States share driver data through a computer database to prevent the issuance of duplicate licenses.

questions.question: To prevent fatigue while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: A hot, poorly-ventilated area can make a person sleepy. Opening a window, opening a vent, or using the air conditioning can help keep the cab cool and reduce the risk of fatigue.

questions.question: You must put out emergency warning devices within ____ of stopping on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of a road, put out your emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping. When pulling off the road to stop, be sure to turn on your four-way emergency flashers.

questions.question: Distracted drivers may be:
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phones.
questions.answerD: Not talking to anyone else in their vehicles.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: If asked to sight-side back your vehicle into an alley, you should first:
questions.answerA: Pull directly into the alley parking space.
questions.answerB: Turn your vehicle to the right to position yourself directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Pull past the alley and stop perpendicular to the outer boundary.
questions.answerD: Pull past the alley and stop parallel to the outer boundary.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered a look?
questions.answerA: Walking to the back of a vehicle to check its position
questions.answerB: Using side mirrors to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerC: Looking out of the driver's side window to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerD: A driver glancing over their shoulder to check blind spots
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: Where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.
questions.answerB: Where the front of each front tire touches the ground.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus; the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside mirrors should allow a bus operator to see how far behind their bus?
questions.explanation: The left and right side flat mirrors on the outside of a school bus should be adjusted so that the driver can see 200 feet (or four bus lengths) behind the bus.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, switch gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the crossing.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror:
questions.answerA: Allows the driver to see what is happening inside of the bus.
questions.answerB: Allows the driver to see what is happening outside of the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: There are blind spots ____ left and right side flat mirrors.
questions.explanation: There are blind spots immediately below and in front of each outside flat mirror. These mirrors have another blind spot directly behind the rear bumper.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: There are blind spots ____ left and right side flat mirrors.
questions.explanation: There are blind spots immediately below and in front of each outside flat mirror. These mirrors have another blind spot directly behind the rear bumper.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, a bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Place the vehicle in third gear.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus should be put in park. If the transmission does not have a park shift point, the vehicle should instead be placed in neutral.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Before evacuating a bus in response to a hazard, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Ask the students if they want to leave.
questions.answerB: Explain the hazard to the dispatcher and make a decision on how to respond.
questions.answerD: Have students open all the windows.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be the safest and the easiest to supervise if they are not evacuated from the school bus. If there is time, the driver should contact their dispatcher to explain the emergency situation before making the decision to evacuate.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: While students load and unload a bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch the process and keep an eye on the students.
questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: The overhead inside mirror should be adjusted to see:
questions.answerA: Outside of the driver’s side of the bus.
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.answerC: Students in the first four rows of the bus.
questions.explanation: The top portion of the overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: Where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.
questions.answerB: Where the front of each front tire touches the ground.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus; the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Stop between 15 and 50 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerB: Stop 100 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerC: Stop 10 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerD: Continue across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: In general, school bus drivers should stop before any railroad crossings to check the tracks for approaching trains. Drivers should stop no closer than 15 feet, and no farther than 50 feet, from the nearest rail in order to have the best view of the tracks. They should look and listen for approaching trains before proceeding through the crossing.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting engine compartment belts during the vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: The belts should be checked for snugness, each with up to three inches of play.
questions.answerB: The water pump belt does not need to be identified.
questions.answerC: The air compressor belt should be removed.
questions.answerD: The applicant must identify which items are not belt-driven, if any.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts. In addition to cracks and frays, you should check the belts for snugness, allowing up to three-quarters of an inch of play at the center of each belt. If any of these items are not belt-driven, you must identify them and ensure that their components are operating properly, are not damaged or leaking, and are mounted securely.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package, a ____ placard must be used.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package or its shipping paper, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate, must be displayed.

questions.question: What should be done if the third column of the Hazardous Materials Table contains the word “Forbidden?”
questions.answerA: The indicated substance should not be transported.
questions.answerB: The indicated substance should be transported by air.
questions.answerC: The indicated substance should only be transported at night.
questions.answerD: The indicated substance should be accompanied by a security guard.
questions.explanation: The third column of the Hazardous Materials Table lists items' hazard classes and divisions. Drivers should never transport a material that is marked by the word "Forbidden."

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: A driver must take the HazMat knowledge test:
questions.explanation: You must take and pass the written English version of the HazMat knowledge test and be cleared through a federal background check before every renewal of your CDL.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening the trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerC: Put on a pair of gloves.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: Unless it is clearly unsafe, what does a driver need to accept a package?
questions.explanation: When the shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect:
questions.explanation: Transporting hazardous materials can be risky. The regulations are intended to protect you, those around you, and the environment.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: The identification number associated with a hazardous material should appear:
questions.answerD: On a bumper sticker on the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It must also appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: As a resource to police and firefighters, the National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 100 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a leaking container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerA: Does not have to be able to move the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Does not need to know about the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must stay within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading and unloading of a tank must be watched by a qualified person. They must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the materials involved; know the procedures to follow in an emergency; and be authorized and able to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect:
questions.explanation: Transporting hazardous materials can be risky. The regulations are intended to protect you, those around you, and the environment.

questions.question: Before any flammable liquids are loaded or unloaded, the engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump.

questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: What shape is a placard indicating hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: How must a shipper notify a driver of the risks associated with their cargo?
questions.answerB: By writing a note on a blank piece of paper
questions.answerC: By putting hazard warning labels on packages
questions.answerD: By placing orange dots on packages
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous cargo must alert drivers and others to relevant hazards through proper shipping papers, hazard warning labels on packages, emergency response information, and placards.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: Shipping papers identifying hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerA: At the bottom of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerB: On the top of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerC: In a location separate from non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Carriers and drivers must be able to quickly identify hazardous materials' shipping papers. Shipping papers for hazardous materials should be on the top of a stack of shipping papers.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.

The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.

The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Sign, but only if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Sign, but only if the weather was hazardous.
questions.explanation: A Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest must be signed by hand. The name and EPA registration number of the shippers, carriers, and destination must also appear on the manifest.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The packages should be carried in the cab.
questions.answerC: The packages should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation surrounds packages of radioactive materials and passes through to other nearby packages. To address this, the number of radioactive packages that can be loaded together is limited.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers for oil, coolant, charging circuits, and the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should go out right away.

questions.question: When driving a double or triple, it is important to remember that:
questions.answerA: The vehicle requires more space than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Other drivers will likely get out of your way when necessary.
questions.answerC: The vehicle likely weighs the same as other vehicles.
questions.answerD: The vehicle can easily fit into small spaces.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples need more space than other vehicles, both because they are longer than other vehicles and because their size and weight prevent them from turning or stopping suddenly. When driving a double or triple, always make sure you have enough space before entering traffic, crossing traffic, or changing lanes.

questions.question: When entering traffic, the driver of a double or triple needs to be aware that doubles and triples:
questions.answerA: Need more space to merge into traffic than smaller vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are exempt from most speed limits.
questions.answerC: Are difficult for other drivers to see.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples need more space than other vehicles, both because they are longer and because their size and weight prevent them from turning or stopping suddenly. When driving a double or triple, always make sure you have enough space before entering traffic, crossing traffic, or changing lanes.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn’t see you.
questions.explanation: It is always safest to assume that other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians don't see you. Be prepared for the possibility that they may suddenly move into your path. It may be safe to lightly tap your horn or flash your lights as you pass.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to result in hydroplaning?
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur on wet roads if tire pressure is low or if tire tread is worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention focused in front of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look only to the front and sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle. In addition to watching the road ahead, you should frequently check your mirrors to monitor the road to the sides and to the rear of your vehicle.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: When using road speed to know when to switch gears, you should:
questions.answerA: Learn what speeds each gear is good for and shift up when necessary.
questions.answerB: Watch other vehicles and try to keep pace.
questions.answerC: Watch other trucks and shift when they shift.
questions.answerD: Use the speed limit as a guide.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both mirrors, as that can cause too much distraction.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you see how they do it.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Especially if you are unfamiliar with the area, you should get out of your vehicle and familiarize yourself with your path of travel before beginning to back up.

questions.question: If driving a vehicle with a manual transmission, you can prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when starting from a stop by:
questions.answerA: Partly engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Placing the vehicle in reverse before moving forward.
questions.answerC: Fully engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Placing the vehicle in neutral before moving forward.
questions.explanation: To prevent rolling backward when starting from a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake. Apply the parking brake whenever necessary to prevent your vehicle from rolling back.

questions.question: If an approaching driver is using their high beam headlights, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your high beam lights to remind the driver to switch to their low beams.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerD: Pull to the side of the road until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is coming toward you while using its high beam headlights, glance away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed. This will keep you from being blinded by the lights.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail for one of two reasons. Which of the following is one of those reasons?
questions.answerA: There is a loss of hydraulic pressure.
questions.answerD: The brakes are used too much in one day.
questions.explanation: Most hydraulic brake failures occur for one of two reasons. A first likely cause of brake failure is that the brakes have been overused on a downgrade, causing them to fade. The second likely cause is that there has been a loss of hydraulic pressure in the braking system. Brakes kept in good condition will rarely fail, but you should know which steps to take in case they do.

questions.question: Starting in which year were newly manufactured trailers required to have ABS?
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: Steering that feels heavy is often a sign of:
questions.explanation: If steering begins to feel heavy, it is likely that one of your front tires has failed. If you feel a change to your steering, you should exit the road as quickly as is safely possible and check your tires.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If pulled off to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow your taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerB: Turn on your emergency flashers to warn other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other motorists.
questions.answerD: Keep your door open to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop and park on the side of the road, make sure to turn on your emergency flashers. This is especially important at night. Taillights are not an adequate when alerting other drivers because the drivers may mistakenly think your vehicle is moving normally and collide with it.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: A double or triple:
questions.answerA: Is usually able to be driven faster than a straight truck.
questions.answerB: Is usually less stable than other smaller commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Is always easier to drive than other commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Does not need a special endorsement to be driven.
questions.explanation: Double and triple trailers are less stable than single commercial vehicles and are more likely to roll over when being driven. To prevent rollovers, doubles and triples must be driven very smoothly and gently.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as a fire extinguisher, is:
questions.answerA: Only needed for vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to result in hydroplaning?
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur on wet roads if tire pressure is low or if tire tread is worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a way to prevent drowsiness during a trip?
questions.answerA: Getting an adequate amount of sleep before driving
questions.answerC: Scheduling trips during hours when you would not normally be awake
questions.answerD: Avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you so you can take turns driving; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a vehicle inspection report?
questions.answerA: It tells the motor carrier about problems that may need to be fixed.
questions.answerB: It ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly.
questions.answerC: It keeps drivers accountable for inspecting their vehicles.
questions.answerD: It provides a plan for the next five trips.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report allows a driver to inform the motor carrier of issues that could affect the safe operation of a vehicle. If required, the driver should fill out a vehicle inspection report after every day of driving. They should make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel) can make it difficult to steer.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: Manhole covers:
questions.answerA: May be open when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.answerB: Should be closed when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.answerD: Should be removed when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.explanation: Be sure to inspect your vehicle before driving. Never drive a tank vehicle with open valves or manhole covers.

questions.question: When loading or unloading a tank that is divided by bulkheads, the person loading the tank should be mindful of:
questions.answerB: Insects coming out of the tank.
questions.explanation: Some tanks are divided into multiple smaller tanks by bulkheads. When loading or unloading such tanks, pay attention to weight distribution. Be careful not to place too much weight on a single end of the tank.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: If a tank is found to be leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive with their flashers activated to warn other motorists.
questions.answerC: Let someone know at the end of the trip.
questions.answerD: Try to fix the leak by welding the opening shut.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to transport liquids or gases in a tank vehicle that contains a leak. If you notice a leak in a tank vehicle that you are operating, get the leak fixed immediately.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor:
questions.answerA: At a 90-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.answerC: At a 30-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerD: At a 60-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: When inspecting the exhaust system for defects, which of the following should be fixed?
questions.answerB: A broken exhaust pipe, muffler, or tailpipe
questions.explanation: Exhaust system defects can be extremely serious because they may make it possible for poisonous fumes to enter into the cab or sleeper berth. Issues to check for in a pre-trip inspection include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, vertical stacks, mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts that are rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: To make it as safe as possible to leave a stop, you should park:
questions.answerA: So that you must back up to leave your parking space.
questions.answerB: So that you can pull forward to leave your parking space.
questions.answerC: On the side of a roadway, not in a parking lot.
questions.answerD: By backing into a parking space.
