questions.explanation: Backing can be dangerous, so avoid doing it whenever you can. If possible, park in such a way that allows you to pull forward to exit your parking space.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: You should always drive at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: You should always drive slightly below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: You should adjust your speed according to conditions.
questions.answerD: You should drive as fast as possible.
questions.explanation: Operators driving too fast is a major cause of fatal crashes. You must continually adjust your speed to a rate that is safe for road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly before other vehicles get into the lane you wish to occupy.
questions.answerB: Move slowly, in case another vehicle is in the lane you wish to occupy.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal before changing lanes.

questions.question: Baffled tanks:
questions.answerA: Are ineffective in preventing front-to-back liquid surge.
questions.answerB: Contain bulkheads with holes, allowing liquid to move among sections of the tank.
questions.explanation: Baffled tanks contain bulkheads with holes to help control the movement of liquid cargo. These bulkheads lower the risk of front-to-back surge, though side-to-side surge may still occur.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.answerD: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: The amount of liquid cargo being loaded into a tank should depend on:
questions.answerA: The speed limits on the route.
questions.explanation: Factors that affect how much liquid is safe to load into your tank include how much the liquid will expand in transit, the weight of the liquid, and legal weight limits. If you are loading a particularly dense liquid, take special care to ensure that you do not exceed legal weight limits.

questions.question: Carrying liquid cargo:
questions.answerA: Is easier than carrying solid cargo.
questions.answerB: Is more difficult than carrying solid cargo.
questions.answerD: Is not permitted during normal business hours.
questions.explanation: Hauling liquids in a tank requires special skill. Due to the danger of liquid surge, carrying liquid cargo is more difficult than carrying solid cargo.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerD: Only use the mirror on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of hazards behind your vehicle when backing, you should frequently check your mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have a helper watch your blind spots whenever possible.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Due to the risk of liquid surge in tanks, you should:
questions.explanation: Be aware of the risk of liquid surge when driving tanks transporting liquid cargo. To prevent the negative affects of surge on your driving, you should start, slow, and stop very smoothly.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: You must put out emergency warning devices within ____ of stopping on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of a road, put out your emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping. When pulling off the road to stop, be sure to turn on your four-way emergency flashers.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important that you turn on your emergency flashers as a warning to other drivers. This is especially important if you are stopped at night.

questions.question: If you identify a distracted driver on the road, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter a distracted driver, make sure to give them plenty of room. Be very careful if you pass their vehicle because the driver may be unaware of your presence and drift into your lane.

questions.question: Mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: When you are standing next to the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be checked prior to the beginning of a trip. On a vehicle with a trailer, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the connected trailer is straight.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.answerD: Only encouraged if you are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If a roadway is covered by fog, it is best for you to:
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous. If possible, you should always avoid driving under foggy conditions.

questions.question: After the engine is started, warning lights and buzzers should all:
questions.answerD: Turn off once the vehicle begins moving.
questions.explanation: After the engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers should deactivate immediately. The charging circuit warning, oil, coolant, and Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) lights should all turn off.

questions.question: When loading a tank, space should be left for outage. What is outage?
questions.answerD: A place for luggage and personal items
questions.explanation: Liquids expand when warmed, so a tank carrying liquid must also contain additional space to accommodate for this expansion. The extra space is known as "outage."

questions.question: Over-the-counter medication:
questions.answerA: Poses no safety risks to a driver.
questions.answerB: Is not referenced by any laws regarding driving under the influence.
questions.answerD: Can affect a person’s ability to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications may have side effects that can impair a person's ability to drive safely. It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any other controlled substance, including some over-the-counter medications.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerD: While minimizing the vehicle's fuel use.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: When checking the springs during a vehicle inspection, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ensure torsion springs are not damaged.
questions.explanation: When checking the springs as part of the vehicle inspection test, you should look for missing, shifted, cracked, or broken leaf springs, as well as broken or distorted coil springs. If the vehicle is equipped with torsion bars, torque arms, or other types of suspension components, ensure that they are not damaged and are mounted securely.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: How many classes of hazardous materials are there?
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: If driving in a foggy area, you should not:
questions.explanation: It is safest not to drive in foggy areas. However, if you must drive through fog, you should slow down, use your low beam headlights and fog lights, and turn on your four-way flashers.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When driving in heavy traffic, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your cell phone for texting instead of calling.
questions.answerD: Turn up the ringer on your cell phone.
questions.explanation: Areas with heavy traffic, road construction, large numbers of pedestrians, or severe weather demand extra attention from a driver. The driver should avoid all possible distractions while in such areas, including cell phone use.

questions.question: Roads are most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Some tires are not designed for rain.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: If an approaching driver is using their high beam headlights, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your high beam lights to remind the driver to switch to their low beams.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerD: Pull to the side of the road until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is coming toward you while using its high beam headlights, glance away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed. This will keep you from being blinded by the lights.

questions.question: The driver’s seat of a bus should include:
questions.answerA: A pocket for storage on its left side.
questions.answerB: A pocket for storage on its right side.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus must be equipped with a seat belt, which the driver should always use.

questions.question: When starting the engine as part of the pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, you must make sure the cargo is secure:
questions.answerB: Every 150 miles or three hours of driving.
questions.answerC: Only after traveling up a hill.
questions.answerD: Only after coming to a hard stop.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: How much water must be present for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A significant amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is a phenomenon during which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the road surface and begin to glide along on water on the road. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: A driver does not need to inform others of their intentions.
questions.answerB: A driver should only use turn signals if a vehicle is next to them.
questions.answerC: A driver should not use a turn signal if their lane change will be obvious.
questions.answerD: A driver should always use turn signals to inform others of their intentions.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a driver always uses proper signals to make their intentions known to others on the road.

questions.question: In an engine compartment, loose belts will:
questions.answerA: Not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, causing the engine to overheat.
questions.answerB: Make the engine run more efficiently.
questions.answerC: Make the fan run too much, causing the engine to run too coolly.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check the tightness of the belts in your engine compartment. Loose belts will not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, which can lead the engine overheating.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire tread depth is good.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the correct tire was changed.
questions.answerD: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to re-check the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Buses must never transport:
questions.explanation: While buses may carry some hazardous materials under certain conditions, they must never be used to transport tear gas or irritating materials.

questions.question: After the engine is started, warning lights and buzzers should all:
questions.answerD: Turn off once the vehicle begins moving.
questions.explanation: After the engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers should deactivate immediately. The charging circuit warning, oil, coolant, and Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) lights should all turn off.

questions.question: Before driving a bus, you must:
questions.answerA: Review its most recent inspection report.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: Federal and state laws require:
questions.answerA: Drivers to regularly inspect their vehicles.
questions.answerB: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they believe there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Drivers to inspect their vehicles if planning to travel out-of-state.
questions.answerD: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they will be transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Commercial drivers are required by federal and state laws to inspect their vehicles before every trip. Regular inspections can help drivers identify issues before they become dangerous and costly.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Always comes as a result of physical distraction, not mental distraction.
questions.answerB: Can be elevated by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations while driving.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, do not engage in complex or emotionally intense conversations while driving. Pre-programming radio stations before your trip and avoiding eating, drinking, or smoking while at the wheel can also help you avoid becoming distracted while driving. Remember that mental distractions that take your attention away from the task of driving can be just as dangerous as physical distractions.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, switch gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the crossing.

questions.question: When planning to drive a bus that has been parked for a few days:
questions.answerA: The driver should assume the interior is in good working order.
questions.answerB: The driver should call the local police department.
questions.answerC: The driver should do a walkthrough inspection to ensure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: The driver should ask the passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before driving a bus that has been unattended, you should check the interior to confirm that everything is in proper condition.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is not a concern if passengers are not unloading.
questions.answerC: Should not be on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Is a concern, whether passengers are visible or not.
questions.explanation: Always drive cautiously around a stopped bus. Passengers may cross in front of or behind it, and the bus may prevent them from seeing your vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: Before driving a bus that has been parked for a few days, a driver:
questions.answerA: Can assume the interior is in good working condition.
questions.answerB: Should call the local police department to inspect the bus.
questions.answerC: Should do a walkthrough inspection to make sure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: Should ask passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before beginning a trip, a bus driver should check the interior of a bus to verify that key systems are in good condition for rider safety.

questions.question: When backing, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the passenger’s side mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn toward the passenger’s side whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: Once stopped as part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep the vehicle in first gear.
questions.explanation: When parking as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must apply the parking brake. The gears should be shifted into neutral or park. You must be parked parallel to the curb and should not be blocking any driveways or intersections.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: Buses must never carry ____ in the space occupied by passengers.
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in the area occupied by passengers.

questions.question: How can you tell if a bus is traveling around a banked curve at too high a speed?
questions.answerA: The bus is leaning toward the outside of the curve.
questions.answerB: The bus is leaning toward the inside of the curve.
questions.answerD: An alarm will go off on the bus's dashboard.
questions.explanation: If a bus is leaning toward the outside of a banked curve, it is being driven around the curve at too high a speed. Drivers should reduce their speeds when approaching curves, especially when operating large vehicles, such as buses.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Applying the brake pedal causes air pressure to activate an electric switch and:
questions.answerB: Turn on the low pressure warning light.
questions.answerD: Turn off the low pressure warning light.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: How should you test the low pressure warning signal?
questions.answerA: Engage and disable the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly press and release the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Uncouple and recouple all glad hands.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: What happens if the air pressure in a system's air tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light will come on.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will not shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low pressure warning signal should activate if the pressure in the air tanks falls to a level below 60 psi. This signal may be in the form of a warning light or a wig wag.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: Which type of brakes do most heavy-duty vehicles have?
questions.explanation: For safety, most heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: Where is the safety relief valve usually located?
questions.explanation: An air brake system's safety relief valve is located in the tank that is first to receive air from the compressor.

questions.question: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerC: Push against the inside of the drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Each system has separate air tanks, hoses, and lines.
questions.answerB: The systems share air tanks, but each has its own separate hoses and lines.
questions.answerC: Each system uses the same lines and hoses.
questions.answerD: One system is the main braking system and a second system is ready to be used if the first one fails.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Remove the drum and look inside.
questions.answerD: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Front wheel braking works:
questions.answerC: Only if the road is dry.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: Look for matching colors when coupling glad hands. Service lines are often:
questions.explanation: When coupling glad hands, make sure to couple together matching glad hands. To help drivers avoid mistakes, color coding is sometimes used. Service lines are often coded with the color blue and emergency lines are often coded with the color red.

questions.question: To help prevent rollovers, you should:
questions.answerC: Keep the load near the back of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Keep the load on one side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: After coupling, there should be ____ between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: Emergency air lines are often coded with the color:
questions.explanation: In general, the parts of the service air line are coded blue and the parts of the emergency air line are coded red.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, how should you turn the steering wheel?
questions.answerA: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerD: It depends on where the trailer is being backed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once the trailer begins turning, you should then switch the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerC: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will permit you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: What is off-tracking?
questions.answerA: When a vehicle’s front wheels follow a different path than its rear wheels
questions.answerB: When a vehicle's wheels all follow the exact same path
questions.answerC: When a load shifts during a turn
questions.answerD: When a vehicle's wheels run over a curb during a turn
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is known as off-tracking, or "cheating."

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand brake while experiencing a trailer jackknife will:
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a trailer jackknife, you can help your tires regain traction by releasing the brakes. Using a trailer hand brake while experiencing a skid will only cause the skid to continue.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Starting in which year were newly manufactured trailers required to have ABS?
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push the tractor air supply control, you should:
questions.explanation: It is important that all of your vehicle's equipment is in proper working condition before you begin a trip. If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push in the tractor air supply control, you should make sure the air line connections are properly attached and sealed.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: One way to prevent a rollover is to:
questions.answerA: Move cargo to the left side of the rig.
questions.answerB: Keep cargo centered on the rig.
questions.answerC: Move cargo to the right side of the rig.
questions.answerD: Keep cargo as far from the ground as possible.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The turn should be made as tightly as possible.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels move in different paths.
questions.answerC: The rear wheels should run over the curb.
questions.answerD: It is acceptable for street signs to be knocked over if they are too close to the road.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Rollovers are most likely to happen when:
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when an operator turns too fast. Drivers should be sure to slow down before entering turns and curves, especially when transporting a fully-loaded rig.
